newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Bangladesh, Philippines team up to protect workers.
newsitem.headline: Bangladesh, Philippines team up to protect workers.

text.p: Bangladesh and the Philippines on Wednesday agreed to cooperate on a wide range of issues from protecting the rights of their expatriate workers to resolving insurgencies.

"We agreed to work closely in promoting the interest and welfare of our migrant wrokers," President Fidel Ramos of the Philippines told a news conference in Dhaka after talks with Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina.

Ramos said his country was ready to host an international conference on migration so that the countries sending workers abroad could forge a "core group" to pursue an early ratification of the U.N. convention on the issue.

"This is very crucial to my country, which has 3.9 million expatriate workers in 135 countries," said Ramos, who arrived in Dhaka on Wednesday on a three-day visit to Bangladesh on the second leg of his trip to South Asia and the Middle East.
"I share the same view. They (migrant workers) are contributing to the economies of the host countries. They must enjoy their due rights," Hasina told the new conference.
Bangladesh has nearly two million nationals working abroad, remitting home about $1.2 billion annually.
The Bangladesh prime minister said she had assured the Filipino leader of her government's continued support for solution of the insurgency in the southern Philippines.
Bangladesh is one of six members of a committee of the Organisation of Islamic Conference (OIC) that is trying to help end the separatist Moro Islamic Liberation Front insurgency.

Hasina said she had expressed interest in cooperation between the South Asian Association of Regional Cooperation (SAARC) and the ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations), of which the Philippines is a member. She did not elaborate.
The two leaders have agreed to reactivate existing joint committees to bolster trade and investment ties.
"These committees should be tasked to intensify their efforts. Our bilateral trade is too modest. We need to increase it," Ramos said.
Ramos, leading a 120-member delegation that includes top businessmen, leaves for Pakistan on Friday.
